Title: How to prove that minimum of two exponential random variables is another exponential random variable?
Content: How can I prove that the minimum of two exponential random variables is another exponential random variable, i.e. Z = min(X,Y)
AcceptedAnswer:
Note that you must assume that $X$ and $Y$ are independent,
otherwise the result is easily seen to be false. There is a constant $\lambda$ such that 
$P(X \geq t)=e^{-\lambda t}$ for every $t>0$. There is a constant $\mu$ such that 
$P(Y \geq t)=e^{-\mu t}$ for every $t>0$. Then for every $t>0$ we have $$
P(Z \geq t)=P(X\geq t,Y\geq t)=P(X\geq t)P(Y\geq t)=e^{-(\lambda+\mu)t}
$$ So $Z$ is an exponential random variable with
parameter $\lambda+\mu$.
